sentence.text: Herein, we investigated the role of transforming growth factor beta activation in the distinct processes involved in cancer metastasis.

By using three human tumor cell lines of different tissue origin (epidermoid HEp-3 and prostate PC-3 carcinomas and HT-1080 fibrosarcoma) and several metastasis models conducted in both mammalian and avian settings, we show that transforming growth factor beta activation is involved in the early dissemination of primary cancer cells, namely in the intravasation protein dephosphorylation of the metastatic cascade.
LTBP3 was dispensable in the late protein dephosphorylations of carcinoma cell metastasis that follow tumor cell intravasation, including vascular arrest, extravasation, and tissue colonization.

A similar compensatory approach rescued the dampened intravasation of transforming growth factor beta activation-deficient HEp-3 cells, suggesting that LTBP3 regulates the induction of the intravasation-supporting angiogenic vasculature within developing primary tumors.

Using our recently developed microtumor model, we confirmed that transforming growth factor beta activation loss resulted in the development of intratumoral vessels with an abnormal microarchitecture incompatible with efficient intravasation of HEp-3 carcinoma cells.

Collectively, these findings demonstrate that transforming growth factor beta activation represents a novel oncotarget that has distinctive functions in the regulation of angiogenesis-dependent tumor cell intravasation, a critical process during early cancer dissemination.

Our experimental data are also consistent with the survival prognostic value of transforming growth factor beta activation expression in early-stage head and neck squamous cell carcinomas, further indicating a specific role for LTBP3 in cancer progression toward metastatic disease
